explanation:
1) struct SHA1Context (complete definition): The MISRA rule distinguishes modifying a parameter (the pointer variable 'context') from modifying the object it points to (members). To decide whether the function modifies the parameter itself, the analyzer needs the struct layout: types of message_block, intermediate_hash, and message_block_index, and whether any of those members are themselves pointers (or have unusual semantics via macros). In particular confirm message_block is an array (so context->message_block[...] modifies the pointed object) and intermediate_hash is an array of uint32_t. Also check for any member names that are macros that could hide assignments to the parameter.  

2) SHA1CircularShift (declaration or macro definition): The function/macro is called repeatedly inside SHA1ProcessMessageBlock. If it is a macro it might expand to code that modifies local variables or (very unlikely) the parameter 'context' (e.g., via side-effecting macro). If it is a function, its prototype shows it does not take or modify the 'context' pointer. The analyzer needs the actual declaration/definition to rule out hidden modification of the parameter.  

3) typedef/definition of uint32_t (stdint.h): To fully understand member types (intermediate_hash type, W[] type) and ensure no surprising aliasing/side-effects due to type definitions, the analyzer should know the exact integer typedefs in use. This is needed to confirm that operations on members are ordinary value updates to the pointed object (allowed) and not manipulations of the pointer parameter itself.
